title: Eclecticism in music
text: In music, eclecticism is the conscious use of <a href="Music%20genre">styles</a> alien to the <a href="composer">composer</a>'s own nature, or from a bygone <a href="Dates%20of%20classical%20music%20eras">era</a>. The term is also used pejoratively to describe music whose composer, thought to be lacking originality, appears to have freely drawn on other models. This word can also be used to describe the music of composers who combine multiple styles, such as using a <a href="Whole%20tone%20scale">whole-tone</a> variant of a <a href="Pentatonic%20scale">pentatonic</a> folksong over <a href="Diatonic%20and%20chromatic">chromatic</a> <a href="counterpoint">counterpoint</a>, or a <a href="tertian">tertian</a> <a href="Arpeggio">arpeggiating</a> melody over <a href="Quartal%20and%20quintal%20harmony">quartal</a> or <a href="secundal">secundal</a> harmonies. Eclecticism can also occur through <a href="Musical%20quotation">quotations</a>, whether of a style, direct quotations of folksongs/variations of them (for example, in Mahler's Symphony No. 1 - <a href="https%3A//www.youtube.com/watch%3Fv%3DiBKd78WUa74">2nd</a> and <a href="https%3A//www.youtube.com/watch%3Fv%3DRQCHgnpCGf4">3rd</a> movements) or direct quotations of other composers (for example, in Berio's <a href="https%3A//www.youtube.com/watch%3Fv%3D9YU-V2C4ryU">Sinfonia - 3rd movement</a>).
